p: Recently, Birhanu et al. reported that D. morbifera (125, 250, and 500 mg/kg) administration orally daily for 14 days triggered an increase in spleen cells in mice. In addition, T-cell phenotypic investigation indicated that D. morbifera-treated groups showed higher CD8a+, CD11b, and CD3+ T-cell expression, and the significant suppression of inflammatory cytokines. Moreover, the IgG super-family was significant downregulated in a concentration dependent manner by D. morbifera administration of 4.5%, up to 43.7% [ 27]. The growing level of splenic B- and T-cells upon treatment with D. morbifera plant extracts suggests a T-cell-mediated immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory effect on the immune system.
